title: Friday, 13th July, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:09 am
BE11:09am

I mean, there's an obvious picture to start today.

Deep Breath everyone... Morning all
Blank canvas good morning everyone
Manxish Morning each, happy Friday
Grouchmonkey Buongiorno
BE11:09am

(Good morning, BTW. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily etc with the etc.)

Soundbuy Morning........
SoS nappy Friday
BE11:10am

But you'll no doubt have seen the big inflatable baby hanging over Parliament Square about 500,000 times already this morning.

11:11 am

In addition to those big weird sinister tri-copter things, that went over my house at about half-eight on their way to loop North London for a while.

It's been a morning of "watch the skies"

fortyeight Is it Boris?
BE11:12am

Which is fine, because there's not much to watch in the markets.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

We are in "trade war fears ease" mode, though I'm not entirely clear why or on what basis.

Tom Dalgleish I have the impression UK stocks are less volatile than Oz

We also have sterling taking a bit of a slide on this: https://www.ft.com...-a29d-73e3d454535d

BE11:14am

US President Donald Trump has begun his first official visit to Britain with an undiplomatic barrage against Theresa May, saying the prime minister’s Brexit blueprint “will probably kill” any bilateral trade deal between the two allies.

“If they do a deal like that, we would be dealing with the EU instead of dealing with the UK, so it will probably kill the deal,” Mr Trump told the Sun newspaper. Mr Trump also criticised her handling of the Brexit talks as “very unfortunate”.

Grouchmonkey Inmarsat has gone a bit post-excitement
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Give the Sun some traffic for the full thing, which is a very tiring read: https://www.thesun...rexit-us-deal-off/

undefined

Otter Hello nice internet friends

Swedish Chef Morning. First time I’ve bought the super soaraway Sun for a while. Just the one t*t on page three.
Otter Do you all have exciting plans for the nice weekend?
11:17 am

And first off -- we still don't have anything to say on Inmarsat!

Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 533.00, down 29 (-5.16%), High: 579.40, Low: 528.60, Volume: 1.24m

There's a Deutsche Bank note around titled -- "Inmarsat : Back to business; focus returns to the numbers"

11:19 am

Peace and Love @ Otter I dunno where to rank on the scale of "exciting plans for the week-end" going to France to visit my dying Dad. Please advise ;-)
BE11:20am

With ISAT having rejected EchoStar's improved proposal and
the Board stressing it remains highly confident in the independent strategy, it is down to management to detail the growth prospects ahead. Whilst we remain supportive of the near-term trends as well longer-term growth opportunities, we think management will have to be very clear on how its' 'value creation pyramid' will play out. We think Q2 results on 2 August should build on the reassuring Q1 print, please see the note for detailed forecasts. Our recent discussions with investors highlights increased appetite as long as management clarifies future growth drivers. BUY.

Manxish @Otter - heavy drinking punctuated by a journey on an old steam train

Alchemy30 Strong today
Alchemy30 (morning)

cheeckychappy @BE - weren't u suggesting Dunelm was a bid target?
panda morning!
BE11:26am

The rumour, you'll remember, was that the Adderleys might be interested in taking it private.

Maverick Morning gents, I've digested plenty of recent articles surrounding TP ICAP (nicely covered) and now its been a couple of days wondered if you have any new thoughts please Bryce. Is there more to come out of the wood-work...?
cheeckychappy or still is...?

11:27 am

BE11:28am

BornCynic @grouchmonkey - he would appear to have a health problem - "sciatica sustained in a car crash".
nichoman interesting to compare fortunes of NEX and TP ICAP since sale of voice broking. TP ICAP looks v cheap now...should come good at some point but don't see any need to rush
FATDAZ re Dunelm is there much in theri offering that they couldn't sell on line or that a competitor could really cant see the attraction myself
BE11:29am

Anyway, today's strength looks rather peculiar in the context of yesterday's warning and, while liquidity is rather tight so they tend to be volatile, I'm sure everyone connected to Dunelm knows their responsibilities to keeping an orderly market.

Maverick Concur, interims due 7th August
11:29 am
undefined

cheeckychappy @BE - Meow to the Adderleys then...
Stateless @BE Might look awkward, definitely is not a sell signal

TP ICAP mentioned ...... Not much new, and probably a bit high risk ahead of the interims in August.

TP ICAP PLC (TCAP:LSE): Last: 266.30, down 5.2 (-1.92%), High: 277.90, Low: 265.20, Volume: 936.02k
VV75 Any comments you might have come across concerning Altran would be appreciated.

BE11:34am

(@Tom: absolutely not. If there's enough in the public domain to identify the person it's defamation. Newspapers have been done based on page layouts, where stories have been placed alongside each other innocently.)

FATDAZ @soundbuy thanks for the insight
BornCynic @Grouchmonkey - well, if you ar right, then he obviously has good friends that are willing to cover for him. Either that or he has a lot of dirt on people.............even tiny Luxembourg has state security services "Haut Commissariat de la Sécurité Extérieure" .

Both headcount and non-compensation cost synergies have been revised as TP Icap saw a continued focus on the previous £100m target as damaging innovation and potentially reducing the longer-term value of the platform.

FATDAZ re Junker was surprised to read he was only 63
BE11:36am

And highlights upward pressure on broking compensation rates.

Patience @BE - I used to lay out my university newspaper. Stories are not placed 'innocently' :-)

BE11:36am

TP Icap anticipates these rates to rise from 50.5% in FY17 to over 51% after a period of decline as industry pressure builds. We estimate every 0.5% increase in broker compensation rates would add a further c.£8m to the cost base.

BE11:36am

They're on 290p.

which is 9.25x FY20e EPS discounted back

Folks, please stop asking if things are libelous. The answer is invariably "probably".

I spent two years in a going to media law lectures twice a week in a cold, windy church in Edinburgh and the upshot is: "you're probably stuffed, so don't."

hornblower any grey on Telit selling the crown jewel auto division for $105m. muted reaction given short base

BE11:43am

..... assuming I can find it, which I can't. Nothing in the UBS morning sum.

Paper Chase Shire slowly floating upward also, I note.
Grouchmonkey Can we discuss Telit without being libellous? Tricky area....
Maverick @hornblower Mr Harrington over at Betaville called it once again
BornCynic Niles Pratley over in the Guardian did a good article on Sky - worth a read.
11:44 am
BE11:44am

What there is is a quite interesting note on Next, which is among the better of the retailers this morning.

Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 6,202, up 154 (+2.55%), High: 6,224, Low: 6,068, Volume: 203.79k
BE11:45am

The UBS Evidence Lab Price Intelligence team has collected more than 3m price records for Next products. These show the average price before promotion (unweighted) has risen by c10% over the last 18 months, reflecting adverse FX. As a result, we believe that Next has protected its gross margin, and, with sell-through likely to have been good in Q2, stock into Sale should be down yoy. Although Next has guided to higher clearance costs of Sale garments, we believe the overall H1 gross margin could be slightly up yoy.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

We stand c1.5% above Next's FY18 PBT guidance of £717m, which was raised £12m at the Q1 stage. The Q2 update is due on 2 August. We see upside risk, but not enough to move yet. Where we have more confidence is the self-help flowing through the business, especially in Online (improved search, more personalisation, new short term interest free credit option), at a time when industry store closures should free up market share. With close to a 50-50 stores/online sales split, Next has a foot in both camps to take share. With 11.5% Online sales growth in FY19E, we now assume a slower deceleration in outer years which drives 2-4% PBT estimate upgrades. Share buybacks have been faster than expected which gives a slight additional boost to EPS.

Pseudonym Never realised sciatica made you crave wine so much.
BornCynic Apologies - Nils Pratley
BE11:46am

So buy, price target 6600p from 5750p

BornCynic Was in a Bunnings place yesterday - the new owners are trying to squeeze every penny out of the place. Prices up (10% or more), stuff given to kids for free (footballs, baseball caps etc.) are now to be sold for cash money only.
Blank canvas Tate & Lyle down almost 3%. Trade wars, or currencies?

(I seem to remember he was hired for the Guardian by some guy called Paul Murphy. Long-time readers might recognise that name.)

chad_john JP Morgan beats
Maverick @hornblower, just called todays RNS to a Tee (a month or so ago), standard
BE11:50am

Okay, so Telit.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

As the ROTR notes, this one was flagged by Ben, who's been following this thing closely: https://www.betavi...s-said-to-part-10/

Maverick Very good handle on Telit that's for sure!
BE11:51am

Here's the summary via Finncap.

BE11:51am

Telit has confirmed the sale of its automotive division; it is being bought by Hong Kong-listed TUS International, a leading Chinese ADAS developer, for $105m in cash. With the complexities of disentangling the division from the rest of Telit’s worldwide operations, the deal will take several months to complete; however, we expect Telit to receive the cash by year-end. This will eliminate the current $25m net debt and provide great security as well as working capital for future growth. It represents very good value for one of Telit’s fastest-growing but least profitable operations, and will recapitalise as well as lift margins in the remaining business.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Who are, to be clear, house.

BE11:53am

Telit has a new board in and this is all part of the rescue operation, right?

Blank canvas In the spirit of Otter, who is doing what this weekend? Anyone going to the Proms, or the anti-Trump rally?
BE11:54am

As in, nearly $30m of exceptionals at the full year that meant it printed a $49.7m loss.

Cripes, it's a struggle today. We've heard nothing ahead of IWG's July 21 bid deadline, sorry.

IWG Plc (IWG:LSE): Last: 300.40, up 3.8 (+1.28%), High: 300.80, Low: 296.30, Volume: 1.16m
Grouchmonkey You have to sympathise with the new board. It's like herding Cats.
Soundbuy Bon w/end all..........
11:57 am
BE11:57am

(@Grouchmonkey: very good.)

Soundbuy .........and cheers...........
BE11:58am

Stifel had a fairly generic wrap of the situation out yesterday ....

hornblower family trip to see Incredibles 2
Pseudonym Racing yachts... I expect to fair badly...
BE11:59am

After two months of intrigue we should now be entering the final furlong in the race to acquire IWG, with the 21 July deadline fast approaching for the four interested parties (TDR, Starwood Capital, Prime Opportunities and Terra Firma). The unscheduled trading update in June provided a surprise distraction, and we have recalibrated forecasts for the £15-20m reduction in FY18E profit guidance driven by increased growth investment and UK under-performance. Whilst the flagged challenges at older UK centres may concern potential bidders, comfort should be taken from improving mature performance elsewhere and accelerating growth investment, signaling confidence in future prospects. Whilst we continue to view the chances of a successful bid as relatively high, notable downside risk remains if a bid is unsuccessful. Hold.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

........... which, yeah, fair enough. Can't really argue with that.
